title: The Walking Dead star hospitalised during filming
text:
Unsurprisingly, Beta’s outfit is pretty heavy (Jace Downs/AMC)

The Walking Dead star Ryan Hurst had to be rushed to hospital while filming the show’s 10th season after his heavy costume caused him to get heatstroke.

The 43-year-old actor joined long-running zombie drama The Walking Dead earlier this year as Beta, the second-in-command leader to a mysterious group of survivors who disguise themselves with the skins of walkers.

Concealing his true identity with a leather trench coat, layer upon layer of clothing and a mask made from zombie flesh (stylish!), Beta’s weighty costume took its toll on Ryan, who struggled in the heat on set in Georgia.

Speaking to Entertainment Weekly, the actor was asked whether he ‘got hot in that thing’, to which he shot back: ‘Oh my god.’

He continued: ‘I landed in the hospital once this year from heat exhaustion. I’m in a leather trench coat and two layers under that in Georgia in the summer.

‘It’s no joke, man.’

A rose between two thorns: Ryan with Jeffrey Dean Morgan (L) and Norman Reedus (R) (Picture: Lisa O’Connor/AFP/Getty)

And there was us thinking navigating the Circle Line in the summer was bad…

With Season 10 kicking off earlier in October, fans have been eagerly searching the new episodes for clues of what on earth’s to come this series.

And some eagle-eyed viewers struck gold, as they spotted a nice little Rick Grimes Easter Egg worked into the opening credits, which details key moments from the show so far.

With our injured hero Rick (Andrew Lincoln) bowing out five episodes into the show’s ninth series by staring down a horde of undead on a bridge that was built to unite the communities, this scene is remembered in the show’s titles.

In the illustration, a figure stands on one end of the bridge with a gun raised at the walkers as they make their way towards him. Shortly afterwards, the same bridge is up in flames and completely destroyed in the centre, preventing anything from getting across.

This is likely in reference to the moment Rick fires his gun at a stack of dynamite, killing the walkers and – seemingly – himself to the dismay of the rest of the survivors.
